calendar.p: The Julian calendar, as used in England before 1752. The year starts on March 25.

A Hebrew calendar dating from the creation of the world, based on biblical genealogy. The start date varies according to the biblical texts used. Here, based on the dates given for the same events in other formats, this calendar starts in 3962 BC.
A calendar dating from the Roman discovery of Britain. Based on the dates given for the same events in other formats, this calendar starts in 50 BC.

list.item:
Custome is the chiefest Rule to deter=
myne matters of honour

Consuetudo in vnaquaque Regione, est
omnium dignitatum & iurisdictionum origo
forma & principium

Consuetudini standum est, disponenti
de Nobilitate.

Consuetudines loci faciunt quem nobilem
qui alias non esset nobilis.

Creations of noble men were before
any parliament, which began but in the tyme
of kinge Henry: 3d.

A man vsinge the Titles of .2. seueralle
Baronies: by writte of sommons shall have
his denomination only of one of them.

The Dignity of a Baronesse is parcell
of her inheritance.

No Kinge may be deposed for that he
is an infante

A kings infancy is supplied by the ripe
age of Counsellours. & womens weak
sexe by theire husbands discretion.

Women hold Lands by knight service
& Grand Sergeantye

Wisdome is not denied women by na=
ture

Husbands Tenants in theire wyves rightes -
John. Duke: of Lancaster: in his wives right was
Lord: highe Steward of England:
Sir Lionell dymocke (as Tenante by
curtesy) the kinges Champion.
Margaret: Countesse of Norfolk. dowghter: & heire
of Thomas: of Brotherton, Countesse Mar=
shall of Englande.

Barons take place acordinge to the Anci=
enty of theyre Creations: not as they be
Somaned

Triall at the Comon Lawe is by Juries
At the Ciuile Lawe by depositions
Doctors of the Cyuile Lawe called to
assist the Constable: & marshalle in
trialls of matters of nobilitye and
Chiualry.

The issues in these causes must relie
vpon the Customes of Chiualry vsed within
this Realme.

Women are vncapeable of dignities
with adminestration, not of dignities
of byrthe

Duke & Earle (amonge the Romaynes)
denote an office & dignity in campe
& that of Earle abased to the office of master
of mettalls.

After translation of the empire Dignities
of office became dignities of patri=
monye: & so the stiles of dignities be=
came parcell of inheritance. & patrimonye.

Nobility or dignity coninoyned to the
ffeee descendeth to whom the fee
descendeth: but separate therefrom
the ffeodale, descendeth as the
custome of eche particuler province
or Region

Barons seeme to have bene the
chiefest Captaines of people habi=
tation or Conquest.

Nobleme n are called peers quasi
pares because for the most parte
they are of equall authority

In this Realme Earldomes & Ba=
ronies before the Conquest were
Inheritances in ffesimple & descen=
ded to ffemales aswell as to m
Males: & theire dignities were
anexed to the ffees.

ffeetaile is but a late Invention
aboutEdward: 3d. tyme.

Earles & Barons were many
yeares before any parliament within
this Realme. especially in suche
solempne order.

Auncient Barons at the Conqueste
of England:
Baronies geven to Religious houses
the dignity abidinge inseparate. by
meanes whereof Abbotes Bishops
& Priors which then receaved the style
of Lordes. who otherwise wer in
capeable of suche seculer style
&c
Abbotes & Priours: not endued with such
neither vsed such style nor
were somoned to parliament
Abbotes & Pryors owe service in
parliament in respecte of their
Baronies.
Barons are surnamed of the
chiefe manour of theyre Ba=
ronye, & so their heires also.
Almost all Ancient Barons are
consumed, either by translation
to greater dignities or by the
Barons warres: 46: Henry: 3.
Writts of Creation throughe Decay
of old Barons & plenty of newe
became presidentes of sommons.
The woorde Peeres distinguisheth
Barons created from suche as are
to be created.
Res patrimoniales euer have
bene & ought to be heritable.
Creation of barons is in re=
spect of the service that he & hys
heires are bound to doe to the
Realme & prynce
